item.title: VIM Cheat Sheet
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: Multiple Files Buffers Command Info :w write (save) changes to file :wa write all changed files :w !sudo tee % write out the current file using sudo (use case?) :e foo or :edit foo edit a file in a new buffer :r foo or :read foo or :read !foo read a file or output of shell command :10read foo read and insert file / shell output after line 10 :bn or :bnext switch to the next buffer :bp or :bprev switch to the previous buffer :b4 switch to buffer number 4 :bf switch to first buffer :bl switch to last buffer :b foo<TAB> switch to buffer foo :bd delete a buffer (close a file) :ls or :buffers list all open buffers :set autoread configure to reload stale, out-of-date buffers from disk :checktime force reload out-of-date buffers from disk set hidden hide buffers when abandoned set splitbelow, set splitright new split panes at bottom, right Windows Open & Close Command Info :sb foo<TAB> split window and edit file / buffer :sp or :sp foo split window in two or edit file in new split window :10sp foo new split 10 lines tall :vs foo<TAB> open a file in a new buffer and vertically split window :vert sb N open buffer #N in left vertical split :vert belowright sb N open buffer #N in right vertical split CTRL-W T turn window into new tab CTRL-W o close all windows but the current (in the current tab) CTRL-W q quit a window Configure Command Info CTRL-W = normalise split window sizes CTRL-W R swap top/bottom or left/right split CTRL-W + or - inc or dec height; add w + N for multiple lines CTRL-W > or < inc or dec width; add w + N for multiple columns set number, set nonumber show, hide line numbers set nu!

item.title: Computing Quiz
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: 1 The more hosts the hypervisor manages, the more resources it needs. Show Answer function showAnswer(divId) { var x = document.getElementById(divId); if (x.style.display === 'none') { x.style.display = 'block'; } else { x.style.display = 'none'; } } 2 What is vertical scaling? Show Answer e.g. Getting a bigger box with faster CPU and better I/O can often improve latency and throughput, allowing you to process more work in less time.

Show Answer THEY … - DO always sound the consonant .

item.title: Test-Driven Development Quiz

item.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, et velit nihil nullam vim, id vim tacimates praesent repudiandae, qui et consul diceret fuisset. 1 Show Answer Outside of perhaps explaining a “why,” if you need a comment to explain your test, it stinks. function showAnswer(divId) { var x = document.getElementById(divId); if (x.style.display === 'none') { x.style.display = 'block'; } else { x.style.display = 'none'; } } 2 Show Answer Test-drive new behavior into your system in quite small increments.

item.title: ØMQ Quiz #3
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: This quiz is based on the ZeroMQ Guide written by Pieter Hintjens. 1 What aspects of control vs data flow when designing a protocol? Show Answer Control dialogue tends to last a short time, involing few messages. The data flow could last for hours or days, involing billions of messages. Control is where “normal” errors happen e.g. not authenticated, not found, censored etc. Errors during data flow are exceptional (disk full, server crashed).

item.title: ØMQ Quiz #2
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: This quiz is based on the ZeroMQ Guide written by Pieter Hintjens. 1 Why not use ROUTER instead of PAIR sockets? Show Answer ROUTER wraps your message in an “envelope”, meaning a zero-size signal message turns into a multipart message. If you don’t care about the data and treat anything as a valid signal, and if you don’t read more than once from the socket, that won’t matter.

item.title: C++ Quiz #2
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: 1 What is an lvalue? Show Answer An expression that yields an object or function. A nonconst lvalue that denotes an object may be the left-hand operand of assignment. function showAnswer(divId) { var x = document.getElementById(divId); if (x.style.display === 'none') { x.style.display = 'block'; } else { x.style.display = 'none'; } } 2 What is an rvalue? Show Answer Expression that yields a value but not the associated location, if any, of that value

item.title: C++ Quiz #1
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: 1 Explain why you might want to define your own type-specific swap function? Show Answer function showAnswer(divId) { var x = document.getElementById(divId); if (x.style.display === 'none') { x.style.display = 'block'; } else { x.style.display = 'none'; } } 2 Show Answer Valuelike copy-assignment operator. It is crucially important that the left-hand operand is destroyed and the right-hand operand is copied in a sequence that is correct even if an object is assigned to itself.

item.title: C# Quiz
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: 1 What are the differences between structs and classes? Show Answer Unlike in C++, the default access level for both is private. Their memory allocation models are different. A struct is a value type and its instances are created on the stack. A class is a reference type and its instances are created on the heap. function showAnswer(divId) { var x = document.getElementById(divId); if (x.style.display === 'none') { x.

item.title: Bio
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: I am a technologist, writer, musician and family man who has spent more than 15 years building software systems. I believe in building software that accurately solves real problems. I’ve built Android apps, Websites, distributed messaging systems, desktop applications and an arduino-based product prototype. Although I do venture into web and mobile development, I spend most of my time and energy building desktop and backend systems in programming languages like C++, Python, Go, C# etc.
